utterances: But Serbia's full return into the western community is not likely to happen until it hands over the major war crimes suspect still in hiding: former Bosnian Serb military leader Ratko Mladic.
Sylvia Poggioli, NPR News, the Hague.
The trial of Myanmar's most famous pro-democracy leader has now stretched to a week.
Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi is charged with violating her house arrest by harboring an American who swam across a lake to her home.
Just the fact that such a trial is going on is a window of sorts into Myanmar's hard-line regime.
We have a correspondent in Myanmar.
His name is being withheld for security reasons, although we'll tell you he's a person whose reporting we trust.
Welcome back to the program.
Thanks, Steve.
And what is the latest from the trial?
Day five of the trial - as you said, Aung San Suu Kyi and two of her companions, and the American, John William Yettaw.
Foreign diplomats and journals are not allowed into the trial.
They were allowed on Wednesday briefly.
And I think that was because the regime was feeling the pressure a little bit from the international community, and what they like to do in these instances is they like a little valve.
They just open it up a little bit and let the pressure ease somewhat and then bang.
So the trial was closed again yesterday, closed again today, although an American diplomat is allowed to go to attend because John William Yettaw is an American citizen.
Okay, I suppose with all these closings to the media it's hard to know what's going on in there and in fact it's hard to understand this story.
It seems so bizarre that someone would swim across a lake to her home, and yet there's serious implications here, aren't there, especially if Aung San Suu Kyi is convicted?
Yeah.
I mean there's very serious implications for her.
But let me just tell you that it got a little bit more bizarre today.
State run media this morning quoted Myanmar's foreign minister as saying that the whole thing was a plot by external forces to smear Myanmar's reputation.
So it's a little far-fetched.
But this is a very serious thing for Aung San Suu Kyi, of course, because if convicted again she gets potentially put either back under house arrest or she gets placed in prison again.
And that means she can't participate in any way in next year's election here.
Now, she's been barred from running as a candidate.
But if she's in jail or if she's under house arrest here, then she's barred from participating at all, and that presents a serious problem for the opposition here.

And you say if she gets convicted again, which is a good reminder that she has repeatedly run afoul of the regime in Myanmar and has repeatedly been placed under house arrest and other kinds of custody over the years.
I do want to ask - because you are in Myanmar, you have an opportunity to move around.
What are you seeing?
What are you hearing on the streets?
I.
GEORGE: And I remember hearing the music, and then - in my child-mind - deciding, like, I'm going to dance onstage.
So I danced on stage.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
...depends on how fast it can flow.
It looks like the blowout itself happening over three months has depleted a significant amount of the reservoir pressure.
And that's why it began at 6,700 pounds per square inch instead of the expected 9,000.
It was at 9,000 at the beginning of the blowout, but that pressure was depleted by a very large hole in the top of the straw that's drawing it out of the reservoir.
That straw has been capped with a cork, essentially, and the pressure is now responding and building back up again.
All right.
We're going to take a short break and come back and talk lots more with Roger Anderson.
Our number, 1-800-989-8255, if you'd like to talk about the Gulf oil geology.
So stay with us.
We'll be right back after this short break.
(Soundbite of music)
You're listening to SCIENCE FRIDAY from NPR.
I'm Ira Flatow.
We're talking this hour about the geology of the Gulf there, where the oil has been - the oil gusher, the BP gusher has been capped.
It's not leaking oil as far as we can tell.
And we're talking with Roger Anderson, who is from Columbia University School of Engineering and Applied Science.
I'm fascinated to hear, Dr. Anderson, about watching oil just seeping out of the seabed.
How do you know if you go next to, let's say, an old capped well that if you see seepage is not coming out of the well, it's coming out of the natural seepage?
Well, that's very easy to tell, actually, because biological communities build up over the natural seeps over the hundreds of years that it seeps out.
And these natural seeps are often the origins of coral reefs.
Hmm.
It's excellent food.
The problem, if too much of it comes out at once, is that it sucks all the oxygen out of the water column and that can be bad.

But in its natural form, it's very fertile ground and you find lots of organisms, from bacterial mats all the way up to worms and the kinds of exotic animals that you perhaps have seen from the mid-ocean ridges as well.
Hmm.
Let's go to Malcolm(ph) in Grants Pass, Oregon.
Hi, Malcolm.
Well, good morning, Ira.
I always look forward to hearing your program every Friday.
I love it.
It's really interesting.
Thank you.
My question has to do with why it's taking so long for this oil to stabilize in pressure.

And I've worked with water systems, pressure tanks, pressure systems and pump design, water system designs, and I realize this is like really penny-ante stuff compared to this huge thing they're dealing with there.
But I'm just amazed that it would take this long to come up and stabilize.
Well, it's probably been significantly depleted by the blowout.
This was a huge blowout.
If you think about the history of blowouts, Spindletop from 1901 was about 100,000 barrels a day, and this one is probably up in the 50-, 60,000 barrel a day range.
That's a lot of fluid to come out of a well reservoir.
And it has to be replaced by either other oil or by the water that's in the pore spaces.
And so, that's a function of the permeability of the sandstone reservoir.
And what you're seeing is how fast it's being replaced.
There's a possibility, though not likely, that it won't be recharged and that they've actually lost all of that reservoir.
Okay.
So the fluid coming in through somewhat porous reservoirs adjacent.
That makes a lot of sense.
Thank you.
All right.
Thanks for calling.
Appreciate it.
Thanks, Malcolm.
A tweet from Iknownot(ph) says, is there any way to retrieve genetic information, preserved DNA from the ancient crude oil?
(Soundbite of laughter)
That's a good question.
And, unfortunately not, because it has undergone all kinds of chemical reactions.
It goes through what's called the kerogen stage where the organisms get turned into a blob of black organic mass.
And that evolves over time into, first, oil and then natural gas as it's cooked basically in a pressure cooker.
That's the rock that it's trapped in.
It also migrates and moves, and so it has no resemblance whatsoever to the organic organisms that it started with.
It ends up purely as a chemical formula.
Mm-hmm.
A question from one of our Facebook members says, I'd be interested to have your guest comment on the nature of the crude oil being produced from the BP well.
From what I've read, it appears to be a heavy crude.
However, the news reports have described the oil as easy to skim.
Yeah, it's got a high gas-to-oil ratio.
All the oil coming out of oil reservoirs has some natural gas in it.
And that changes its ability to move around.
This has a high gas-to-oil ratio and so it's very volatile.
It's not heavy tar oil like the - like in - from Venezuela.
It's not - if you had it in a jug, it would look like a black prune juice-like substance rather than a Karo syrup.
Hmm.
And another tweet comes in.
Let's - from - Rudy Schwartz(ph) says, how much methane is down there?
How does it affect global warming with natural leaks?
Is it being collected?
And there are a couple of tweets about - is there - could a huge methane explosion result from...
Yeah, yeah.
That's a very interesting question from a climate standpoint because the natural gas, as you might guess, has an easier time escaping from these reservoirs than the oil.
The oil is sticky and...
Right.
...liquid.
And the natural gas can get out quicker.
It does not make it to the surface of the ocean floor, however, because the water is so cold that it turns to ice.
Mm-hmm.
Thank you so much.
Thanks for your interest in these important issues.
I like taking chances.
And I really can't get up in the morning and think about the goals of being successful, 'cause what is success?
I mean, it certainly isn't money.
I mean, money helps, but doing something that you really like doing as a profession is really success to me.
And you might have heard of these things called clathrates or gas hydrates.
It forms ice in the porous spaces of the mud and stays there until it's breached by some change in temperature and pressure.
So it's purely a chemical phenomenon.

And if you, say, melted all of the glaciers and the increase the sea level by 100 feet or 100 meters, you would change the pressure and temperature, and you might get a burst of a gas that was dissolved from the solid ice that come charging up to the surface.
This is one of the things we think happened in the Cretaceous during the dinosaur times when the climate globally was much hotter than even on our global warming scenarios...
Mm-hmm.
...say.
Mm-hmm.

One last question, how can you tell and Jane Lubchenco, the head of NOAA - Lubchenco said at one point - and they asked her about the origin of oil and she said at that point, it was a few weeks ago that, oh, this is not the oil from the spill.
This is different oil.
Is it that identifiable, different kinds of oil?
Oh, yeah.
Oil has fingerprints.
And the people at Texas A&M and LSU, for instance, both have libraries of fingerprints.
Now, they're not fingerprints like fingerprints, they're chemical signatures.

So you do an X-ray, like a CAT Scan of the oil and it has a specific mixture of all of those different organic compounds: Propane, butane, octane, all of the things that make up the combination that you get out of a refinery, from oil to gas to grease.
Mm-hmm.
And that's what gives each of the reservoirs a distinctive fingerprint.
